ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Growth and electric properties of (100)-oriented Mn-doped (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3-BaTiO3 thin film by pulsed laser deposition

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Material and Device, Mathematics & Science College

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Mn-doped (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3-BaTiO3 (BNBMT) thin film with the composition near the morphotropic phase boundary was grown on (La0.6Sr0.4)CoO3-electroded SrTiO3 single-crystal substrate by using pulsed laser deposition method. Ascribed to the crystal structure and lattice similarity, (100)-oriented BNBMT film with pure single-phase perovskite structure was obtained through carefully controlling the growth conditions. Enhanced ferroelectric and dielectric properties were obtained with large remanent polarization P r of ∼21 μC/cm2, coercive field E c of ∼7.4 kV/mm and dielectric constant
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ of ∼750 at 1 kHz. The excellent global electrical properties of the BNBMT film are promising for environmentally friendly ferroelectric devices.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Piezoelectric materials, which realize the electrical and mechanical energy conversion through electromechanical coupling, play an important role in ultrasonic transducers, sensors, and actuators [1]. Up to present, the dominant piezoelectric materials are lead-based ones, which exhibit outstanding electromechanical coupling response with the composition around the morphotropic phase boundary (MPB) and attract continuous attention [2]. Nevertheless, lead is toxic, which causes the environment pollution and damages human health. Hence it is quite necessary for us to search for high performance lead-free alternatives. Among them, (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3 (BNT) family was regarded to be one of the superior lead-free candidates offering excellent ferroelectric, electromechanical performance, and good temperature stability [3–5]. In the past decades, various studies have been carried out on BNT-based solid solutions and improved performance was obtained [3–5].

Compared to the ceramic counterparts, growth and characterization of BNT-based thin film is still at an infancy stage. Recently, improvements have been achieved in the growth and characterization of the BNT and BNT-based films [6–12]. Yang et al. fabricated the (Ce, Fe)-codoped BNT on LaNiO3(100)/Si substrates by metal organic decomposition and reduced leakage current, enhanced ferroelectric and dielectric properties were obtained [6]. Quignon et al. prepared BNT films on Pt/TiO x /SiO2/Si substrates by rf-magnetron sputtering and high piezoelectric coefficient of 80 pm/V was obtained but the remanent polarization was relatively low [7]. Although some progress has been achieved recently for BNT-based thin films, the global electrical properties were still lower than the bulk counterparts and traditional lead-based ones.

In order to further improve the ferroelectric and dielectric response of the lead-free thin films for device applications, different routines were utilized such as the utilization of different fabrication methods, introducing buffer layers, and using different substrates [8–14]. Pulsed laser deposition (PLD) method has been well demonstrated to be an effective technique for obtaining oxide thin films with complex composition [8]. Based on PLD method, Wang et al. obtained a lead-free (Bi0.5Na1−x−y K x Li y )0.5TiO3 system on Pt substrate with improved remanent polarization of 13.9 μC/cm2 [9]. In our previous work, (La0.7Ca0.3)MnO3 (LCMO)-buffered BNT-based film was prepared on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate and enhanced ferroelectric properties were obtained with remanent polarization P r of ∼20 μC/cm2 [12]. On the other hand, introduction of the single-crystal substrates were found to be another effective routine to improve the crystalline and electrical performances due to high crystal lattice similarity. Wang et al. grew (Bi0.5Na0.5)0.94Ba0.06TiO3 films on CaRuO3-electroded (LaAlO3)0.3(Sr2AlTaO6)0.35 single-crystal substrate and Abazari et al. obtained (Bi, Na)TiO3–(Bi, K)TiO3–BaTiO3 epitaxial thin films on SrRuO3-coated SrTiO3 substrate [13, 14]. Enhanced ferroelectric and piezoelectric properties were both obtained [13, 14].

In this work, Mn-doped (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3-BaTiO3 with a composition around the MPB was chosen, due to its outstanding electromechanical properties with d 33 as high as 483 pC/N and k t of 0.56 [15]. The corresponding thin film was deposited on (100)-oriented SrTiO3 (STO) single-crystal substrate (the lattice constant a=0.3905 nm) by using PLD method. (La0.6Sr0.4)CoO3 (LSCO) with low electrical resistivity and similar crystal structure (the lattice constant a=0.383 nm) was selected as the bottom electrode [16]. (100)-oriented thin films with enhanced ferroelectric and dielectric properties were obtained.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
The ceramic target with the compositions of (Bi0.5Na0.5)0.935Ba0.065TiO3-0.5 mol% Mn (BNBMT) and LSCO was used for deposition. The traditional solid state fabrication method was utilized and details can be found elsewhere [17]. Both the bottom electrode LSCO films and BNBMT films were deposited by PLD using a krypton fluoride (KrF) excimer laser with a wavelength of 248 nm. (100)-oriented STO single-crystal substrates were adopted and the growth parameters for LSCO and BNBMT films are shown in Table 1.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1(a) and (b) illustrates the XRD patterns of LSCO films deposited on the (100)-oriented STO substrate under different temperatures and oxygen partial pressure. As seen in the figures, all the LSCO films exhibited pure single-phase perovskite structures and (100)-oriented thin films can be well obtained within a wide substrate temperature range of 550–625 ∘C. This can be attributed to the crystal structure and lattice similarity between the LSCO (a=0.383 nm) and STO (a=0.3905 nm). In comparison with the deposition temperature, the crystalline properties of the LSCO films show strong oxygen partial pressure dependence. The XRD patterns of LSCO deposited under different oxygen partial pressure at 625oC are shown in Fig. 1(b). With the oxygen partial pressure decreasing from 30 to 10 Pa, the LSCO diffraction peak became substantially stronger along with the lowest full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of ∼0.4°, indicating the best crystalline properties. Furthermore, the corresponding FESEM surface image of LSCO was also measured and shown in Fig. 1(c). Dense and homogeneous morphologies with fine grain size could be observed. Therefore, the LSCO thin film deposited at 625oC and 10 Pa was chosen as the bottom electrode.
Fig. 1
(a) XRD patterns of LSCO thin film deposited at 550, 600 and 625 ∘C, (b) XRD patterns of LSCO deposited under the oxygen partial pressure of 10, 20 and 30 Pa at 625 ∘C, and (c) FESEM surface images of LSCO film deposited using the optimized conditions

Figure 2(a) shows the XRD of the STO-substrated LSCO-electroded BNBMT film. The XRD patterns for the STO substrate and LSCO thin film are also shown for comparison. As shown in Fig. 2(a), pure single-phase perovskite structure was observed and (100)-oriented BNBMT film was obtained. Formation of the thin film with (100) orientation is attributed to the proximity of the lattice structure and constants of BNBMT, LSCO and STO substrate.
Fig. 2
(a) XRD patterns for the STO single crystal substrate, LSCO thin film and LSCO-electroded BNBMT film, and (b) FESEM surface image of BNBMT film

Figure 2(b) shows the FESEM surface image of BNBMT thin film. A dense and uniform surface is apparent with an average grain size of ∼100 nm. Clear and well-defined squared grain morphologies are observed. Formation of such morphology could be explained using the Winterbottom construction [18]. The grains are stacked like building blocks along (100)-orientation. (100) crystal planes of BNBMT grains were parallel to that of STO substrate and that led to the formation of the squared morphology. The cross-sectional FESEM image shows that the thickness of BNBMT and LSCO film was ∼360 and ∼380 nm, respectively.

The corresponding room-temperature electrical properties are shown in Fig. 3(a)–(c). The ferroelectric P-E loop of the LSCO-electroded BNBMT film was measured under different electric fields at 1 kHz as shown in Fig. 3(a). Well-defined ferroelectric loop with the maximum polarization P m of ∼60.4 μC/cm2, remanent polarization P r of ∼21 μC/cm2 and coercive field E c of ∼7.4 kV/mm was obtained. The P r value was close to those deposited on single-crystal substrates in the literature, much larger than that of BNBMT film deposited directly on Pt (with the P r of ∼11 μC/cm2 in our previous work) and other BNT-based thin films on Si substrate [13, 14, 19]. Furthermore, the large remanent polarization is also close to that of the ceramic counterpart with P r of ∼27 μC/cm2. The coercive field E c of BNBMT film was larger than that of the ceramics counterpart (∼4 kV/mm), which was well-observed in ferroelectric films [13, 14, 19]. This should be correlated with the size, defect pinning effects, non-180° domain wall clamping, and film stress (due to the slightly different crystal constants between BNBMT, LSCO and the substrate) [20, 21]. Besides, a close inspection of the P-E loop indicated that there was a slight offset both in the vertical and positive electric field directions. The vertical shift should be bound up with the pinned domains (such as around the film/electrode interfaces or by defects) while the horizontal shift indicated an internal electric field (∼3.1 kV/mm) which might originate from the defect dipoles (such as by Mn doping) or mechanical clamping effect generated during the film growth [21].
Fig. 3
Room-temperature electrical properties of BNBMT film: (a) ferroelectric P-E loop, (b) dc bias field dependence of the
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ and loss tanδ, and (c) frequency dependence of the
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ and loss tanδ

Figure 3(b) displays the dc field dependence of dielectric constant
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ and loss tan δ measured under 5 kHz. Symmetrical curves with typical butterfly patterns were obtained, indicating the ferroelectric nature of the as-grown film. The hysteretic nonlinearity under different dc bias fields demonstrates that the ferroelectric properties of the films originated from the domain switching [13]. This also indicates that ferroelectric domain structure, in addition to electronic and ionic polarizations, contributed significantly to the polarizability of the film [14]. In addition, it can be found that the electric field corresponding to the two maxima
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ was slightly smaller than the coercive field observed in Fig. 3(a). This may be related to the hysteretic motion of ferroelectric domain under different frequencies. The frequency dependence of dielectric constant
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ and loss tan δ of the capacitor of Au/BNBMT/LSCO were measured under a 50 mV oscillation level as shown in Fig. 3(c). The
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ decreased from 865 to 515 with the frequency increasing from 100 Hz to 40 kHz. At 1 kHz, the
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ and loss tan δ were ∼750 and ∼0.15, respectively. The increase in the dielectric loss and the reduction of the dielectric constant may be due to the relaxation of the dipoles [22]. Compared to those of the LCMO-buffered (110)-oriented BNBMT film (
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ of ∼730 and loss tan δ of ∼0.15) [12], the
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ slightly increased. This is also consistent with the dielectric results observed in the (100)- and (110)-oriented BNT-BT single-crystal with composition around MPB [23].

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
In summary, (100)-oriented BNBMT film was prepared on LSCO-electroded STO single-crystal substrate. Enhanced ferroelectric and dielectric properties were obtained with the P r up to ∼21 μC/cm2 and E c of ∼7.4 kV/mm, and
$\varepsilon_{33}^{T}/\varepsilon_{0}$ of ∼750, entirely comparable to those of the ceramic counterpart. The excellent global electrical properties make it quite promising in future environmental-friendly ferroelectric devices.
